courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Earth System Science

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: This course introduces the concept of the Earth System Science - the study of the Earth as a system consisting of many inter-related and interacting components. The topics of lectures include individual components of the Earth System and their respective roles in the changing system. The emphasis is on interactions among different components of the system-atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, lithosphere, biosphere, and anthrosphere.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.academic_group: Div of Earth Sys & Geoinfo Sci
courses.academic_org: Div of Earth Sys & Geoinfo Sci
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will contribute to understanding of Earth system science, including atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, lithosphere, cryosphere, and anthrosphere, and the interactions between and among these spheres. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introductions
2. Radiation Balance
3. Atmosphere
4. Hydrosphere
5. Cryosphere
6. Biosphere & Lithosphere
7. Geodesy and GNSS
8. Climate Change
courses.required_readings:
* Mackenzie, Fred T., 2010: Our Changing Planet – An Introduction to Earth System Science and Global Environmental Changes. 4rd Edition, Pearson Education, Inc., Upper Saddle River, NJ 07458.
* Skinner, Brian J., Stephen C. Porter, and Daniel B. Botkin, 1999: The Blue Planet – An Introduction to Earth System Science. 2nd Edition, John Wiley and Sons, Inc.
* Wallace, John M., and Peter V. Hobbs, 2006: Atmospheric Science: An Introductory Survey. 2nd Edition, Academic Press.
* Peixoto, José P., and Abraham H. Oort, 1992: Physics of Climate. Springer-Verlag New York, Inc.
courses.recommended_readings:
Our Changing Climate AMS Climate Studies: introduction to climate science by Chad M. Kauffman.

http://www.ametsoc.org/amsedu/online/climateinfo/textbook.html

http://bookstore.ametsoc.org/subject/climate-studies

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Special Topics in GeoInformation Science

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: This course discusses the principles, structures and applications of geographic information systems. It emphasizes on the use of GIS in organizing and managing spatial data, and how to perform spatial analysis with GIS. Topics include hardware/software components, raster and vector data structures, spatial database, spatial analysis and application issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.academic_group: Div of Earth Sys & Geoinfo Sci
courses.academic_org: Div of Earth Sys & Geoinfo Sci
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course discusses the concepts, theories, techniques, and applications of geographic information sciences with special topics on geographic information systems, virtual geographic environments, and their applications.

It emphasizes on the use of GIS in organizing and managing spatial data, and how to perform spatial analysis with GIS. Topics include hardware/software components, raster and vector data structures, spatial database, spatial analysis and application issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to geoinformation science
2. Nature of geographic data and geocoding
3. Map projection and coordinate system
4. Data models & structure – vector & raster Data
5. Web GIS – Mashup web maps using ArcGIS online and Esri’s Story Map
6. Database issues
7. Spatial Analysis - Raster GIS capabilities and Vector GIS capabilities
8. GIS Application - Network Analysis and 3D GIS
9. Virtual Geographic Environment (VGE)
10. GIS for humanities and Social Science
11. Big Data and GIS
courses.required_readings: Chang, Kang-tsung, 2016, Introduction to Geographic Information Systems, 8th Edition, McGrew Hill International Edition. [[G70.212 .C4735 2016]](https://julac-cuhk.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/view/uresolver/852JULAC_CUHK/displayItems?physicalServicesResultId=13163617380003407&institutionCode=852JULAC_CUHK&userId=&skinName=cuhk_newui&leganto=false&newUI=true&mmsId=991034023959703407&holdingKey=HoldingResultKey+%5Bmid%3D22772577480003407%2C+libraryId%3D531586720003407%2C+locationCode%3Dul%2C+callNumber%3DG70.212+.C4735+2016%5D&description=&year=&volume=&expandholdingInfo=false&filterByView=false&displayRegisterToInstLink=false)
courses.recommended_readings:
* Burrough, P. A., McDonnell, R., McDonnell, R. A., & Lloyd, C. D. (2015). Principles of geographical information systems. Oxford University Press. [G70.212 .B87]
* Haklay, M. M. (Ed.). (2010). Interacting with geospatial technologies. John Wiley & Sons. [G70.212 .H34]
* Konecny, G. (2014). Geoinformation: remote sensing, photogrammetry and geographic information systems. cRc Press. [G70.212 .K65]
* Gold, C. (2016). Spatial Context: An Introduction to Fundamental Computer Algorithms for Spatial Analysis (Vol. 12). CRC Press. [G70.217.G46 G65]
* O'sullivan, D., & Unwin, D. (2014). Geographic information analysis. John Wiley & Sons. [G70.212 .O85]
* Kennedy, M. D. (2013). Introducing geographic information systems with ARCGIS: a workbook approach to learning GIS. John Wiley & Sons. [G70.212 .K47]
* Haklay, M. M. (Ed.). (2010). Interacting with geospatial technologies. John Wiley & Sons. [G70.212 .H34]
* Chun, Y., & Griffith, D. A. (2013). Spatial statistics and geostatistics: theory and applications for geographic information science and technology. Sage. [G70.217.G46 C58]
* Fu, P., & Sun, J. (2010). Web GIS: principles and applications. Esri Press. [G70.212 .F8]
* Yang, C., & Huang, Q. (2013). Spatial cloud computing: a practical approach. CRC Press. [G70.217.G46 Y36]

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Transportation Applications of GIS

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: This course provides an overview and hands-on experience in the design, use, and interpretation of Geographic Information Systems for Transportation. Topics covered include transportation layers, transportation related referencing systems, data structures, network structures, urban transportation planning models and other spatial models. At the end of the course, students will have a sound working knowledge of transportation GIS and an ability to work directly with real-life problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students are expected to:
1. Understand concepts central to the study of transportation systems.
2. Understand how GIS is revolutionizing transportation practice.
3. Be able to solve various transportation problems using analytical methods discussed in class and applied in labs.
4. Understand issues that impact the performance of transportation systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of GIS and Transportation
2. Basic Elements of Transportation Networks
3. Mobility and Accessibility
4. Introduction to GIS-T
5. GIS-T Data Representations
6. Shortest Path Problem
7. Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP)
8. Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP)
9. Linear Referencing Systems (LRS) & Dynamic Segmentation (DS)
10. Network Flows and Facility Location Problems
11. Travel Demand Analysis
12. Intelligent Transportation System (ITS)
courses.required_readings: Loo, P.Y., Lai, P.C. and Lin, H. (2006). *Integrating Transportation and Geographic Information Systems*: *A Problem-Solving Approach*. Hong Kong: Institute of Space and Earth Information Science, The Chinese University of Hong Kong.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Miller, H. and Shaw, S.L. (2001). *Geographic Information Systems for Transportation: Principles and Applications*. New York: Oxford University Press.
* Ivan, I., Benenson, I., Jiang, B., Horák, J., Haworth, J. and Inspektor, T. (2015). Geoinformatics for Intelligent Transportation. Switzerland: Springer International Publishing.
* Rodrigue, J.-P., Comtois, C. and Slack, B. (2009) *The Geography of Transport Systems*. New York: Routledge
* Shaw, S.L. (2010). Geographic information systems for transportation: from a static past to a dynamic future, *Annals of GIS*, 16(3): pages 129-140.

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Principles of Hydrology
courses.description: Water is a major formative factor and driving force of the physical and biological environment. Water also provides a logical link between biophysical environment and the society. This course introduces the hydrologic concepts, principles, and techniques that are necessary to understand the occurrence, distribution, and circulation of water that pervades, links, and drives various components and processes of the Earth System. Emphasis will be placed on the various components in the land phase of the hydrologic cycle, including precipitation, evaporation and transpiration, infiltration and soil physics, and surface and subsurface flow to streams. Special topics on hydrologic modeling and impact studies will also be addressed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to hydrologic sciences
2. Precipitation and interception
3. Soil moisture and infiltration
4. Evaporation and transpiration
5. Runoff generation and streamflow
6. Groundwater storage and flow
courses.required_readings:
* Arnell, N, 2002. Hydrology and Global Environmental Change. Prentice Hall, Harlow, England. (UL: GB665.A76 2002)
* Brooks, K.N., P.F. Ffolliott, and J.A. Magner, 2012. Hydrology and the Management of Watersheds (4th Edition). Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa. (UL E-book for online access)
* Davie, T., 2008. Fundamentals of Hydrology. Routledge, London, England. (UL: GB661.2 .D38 2008)
* Dunne, T., and L.B. Leopold, 1978. Water in Environmental Planning. W.H. Freeman and Company, New York, NY. (UL: TD160.D85)
* Maidment, D.R. (ed.), 1993. Handbook of Hydrology. McGraw-Hill, New York, NY. (GB662.5.M35 1993)
courses.recommended_readings:
* Mather, J.R., 1978. The Climatic Water Budget in Environmental Analysis. Lexington Books, Lexington, MA. (UL: GB848.M37)
* Viessman, W., Jr., and G.L. Lewis, 2003. Introduction to Hydrology, 5th Edition. Harper Collins College Publishers, New York, NY. (UL: GB661.2.V44 2003)

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Research Methods

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 401
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 401
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 401

courses.description: This couse will be combined with lectures and group discussion on research proposal prepration, literture review and compilation, academic paper writing, academic report preparation, the organzation and management of academic meetings. Popular academic themes will be discussed in the lectures and discussions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth Sys & Geo Sci
courses.academic_group: Div of Earth Sys & Geoinfo Sci
courses.academic_org: Div of Earth Sys & Geoinfo Sci
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking this course, students are expected to understand how to review journal papers, book chapters, advanced development news or reports. They are also expected to learn how to identify research questions from their review and figure out their own solutions to these research questions. Additionally, they are expected to prepare a research proposal on one research topic they selected.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Literature review
2. Discussion on paper reviews
3. Discussion on Research Proposal Writing
4. Discussion on Proposal Writing and Book Review: Design and Analysis of Experiments
5. Discussion on Proposal Writing and Research Design
6. Discussion on Proposal Writing and Book review and critics on Space-Time Integration in Geography and GIScience
7. Discussion on IPCC AR5 Chapter 13 Sea Level Change
8. Discussion on IPCC AR5 Chapter 8 Anthropogenic and Natural Radiative Forcing
9. Final proposal discussion
courses.required_readings:
* Angela Dean, Daniel Voss. Design and Analysis of Experiments. In Springer Texts in Statistics. Springer, New York, 1999
* Mei-Po Kwan, Douglas Richardson, Donggen Wang, Chenghu Zhou, Space-Time Integration in Geography and GIScience. Research Frontiers in the US and China, Springer. 2015
courses.recommended_readings:
* Chaowei Yang, David Wong, Qianjun Miao, Ruixin Yang, 2011, Advanced Geoinformation Science, CRC Press.
* Michael N. DeMers, 2009, GIS for Dummies, Wiley Publishing, Inc.
* IPCC AR5 Chapters 8 and 13
* ISI Web Knowledge.
* Papers of International VGE conference 2014.

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Terrain analysis and digital terrain modelling
courses.description: Digital terrain modelling is important component of modern geo-spatial information technology. Natural terrain surface can be modelled using digital terrain models to form digital data sets that can further be used for terrain parameter derivation and feature interpretation, This subject aims to introduce students the basic concept of digital terrain modelling and analysis. Methods and techniques will be introduced for digital representation of 3-dimensional terrain surface and data structure of digital terrain data. The analytical tools and methods will also be introduced to derive terrain parameters and to extract geomorphic or terrain features from the terrain data. Applications of digital terrain modelling to hydrology soil, ecology and environment will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Basic concepts and principles of digital terrain modelling
- Data structure of digital terrain models and how it is generated and represented as 3-dimensional surface
- Using methods to derive terrain parameters and extract terrain features from digital terrain models
- Application of digital terrain modelling
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction of DEM
2. Organization & Generation of DEM
3. Visualization of DEM
4. Principle of Digital Terrain Analysis
5. Extraction of Terrain Attributes and feature
6. Extraction of Typical Terrain Feature
7. Hydrological Analysis
8. DEM application in Regional Terrain Analysis & Engineering
9. Uncertainty of DEMs and DTMs
courses.required_readings:
* David F., Ph.D. Maune，Digital Elevation Model Technologies and Applications， Amazon Press，2007
* Zhilin Li, Qing Zhu, Chris Gold Digital terrain modeling: principles and methodology. CRC Press, 2005
* Qiming Zhou, Brian Lees, and Guo-an Tang, Advanced in Digital terrain Analysis, Springer Press, 2007
* Wilson, J.P., Gallant, J.C., 2000, Terrain analysis: principles and applications, John Wiley & Sons, UK

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Information, Health and Public Management

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
meetings.instructor:
Dr. LI Rongrong, 
Professor HE Ying, 
Professor TSE Lap Ah

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
meetings.instructor:
Dr. LI Rongrong, 
Professor HE Ying, 
Professor TSE Lap Ah

courses.description: This course provides an overview in the environmental information, public health, surveying, mapping, and interpretation of geo-survey for supporting the public management. The course topics covered the both sides: the principles, techniques and methodologies of environmental information, geo-survey, as well as the foundations of public management which has crucial relationship with policy-making. At the end of the course, students will have a comprehensive knowledge of geo-survey for supporting the public policy analysis and evaluation, hence the rational and efficient public management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:
1. Grasp the foundations of both environmental information, health and public management
2. Recognize the relationships between geo-survey and public management, and the relationship between public management and public health
3. Structure the right policy problem armed by geo-survey methods for sophisticated and efficient public management
4. Adopt reasonable methodologies to present results provided by geo-survey techniques and interpret their policy implications
5. Explore and perform the public policy analysis using geo-analysis methods comprehensively
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction: Environmental Information, Health and Public Management
2 Understanding Environmental Information
3 Understanding Public Health and Public Management
4 Briefing: Geo-survey in Public Management Analysis
5 Structuring Policy Problems
6 Geo-Survey in Public Management Evaluation
7 Comprehensive Application: Learning from Cases
8 Course Review
courses.required_readings: GIS in Public Policy : Using Geographic Information for More Effective Government, by R. W. Greene, ESRI Press, 2000.
courses.recommended_readings:
GIS for Decision support and Public Policy Making, by Christopher Thomas Jou, Nancy Humenik-Sappington, ESRI Press, 2009.

Studies in Applied Geography and Spatial Analysis: Addressing Real World Issues. Edited by Robert Stimson, The University of Melbourne, Australia and Kingsley E. Haynes, Professor of Public Policy and Director, Institute of Public Policy, George Mason University, US. 2012.

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Introduction to Earth Environmental Simulations and the Applications
courses.description: The course introduces the basic knowledge of earth environmental model simulations. Numerical models serve as important tools for earth environmental research and operations. While the topic of earth environmental modelling is broad, this course will focus on the fundamental concepts of numerical modelling, such as temporal and spatial discretizations, parameterizations, model uncertainty and evaluation. Various components of earth system model will be introduced, including atmospheric general circulation model, regional climate model, weather prediction and land surface model, oceanic general circulation model, air quality model, health assessment model and integrated assessment model. In addition, this course will discuss numerical model design, application and testing. Practical exercises such as weather forecast and air quality prediction are also provided for students to gain technical skills and hands-on experience in modelling.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to
• understand basic concepts and theories of earth environmental modelling,
• learn numerical model design, application and testing,
• gain technical skills and practical experiences of earth environmental modelling,
• select appropriate models for solving given earth environmental problems, and
• apply the knowledge of numerical modelling on their research and career.
courses.course_syllabus: This course will introduce numerical simulation theories and technologies on earth systems which include abiotic complexes of atmosphere, hydrosphere, pedosphere and biotic elements of growth processes and population dynamics. The lectures and tutorials will provide students with basic knowledge on use of High Performance Computing simulations of the earth system dynamics, in particular, the global climate change and the adaptation and risk management.
courses.required_readings:
* Philip J. Rasch, Climate Change Modeling Methodology: Selected Entries from the Encyclopedia of Sustainability Science and Technology, Springer; 2012 edition, 2012.
* Eugenia Kalnay, Atmospheric Modeling, Data Assimilation and Predictability, Cambridge University Press, 2002.
* Martin Beniston, From Turbulence to Climate: Numerical Investigations of the Atmosphere with a Hierarchy of Models, Springer, 1997.
courses.recommended_readings:
1) Luca Bonaventura, René Redler, Reinhard Budich. Earth System Modelling - Volume 2 [electronic resource]: Algorithms, Code Infrastructure and Optimisation. Berlin, Heidelberg : The Authors 2012.
2) Jonathan L. Bamber and Antony J. Payne. Mass balance of the cryosphere: observations and modelling of contemporary and future changes. Cambridge ; New York : Cambridge University Press 2004.
3) Mark Z. Jacobson, Fundamentals of atmospheric modelling. Cambridge ; New York : Cambridge University Press 1999.
4) Philip W Mote; Alan O'Neill. Numerical modelling of the global atmosphere in the climate system. Dordrecht ; Boston : Kluwer Academic Publishers c2000.
5) John H. Seinfeld, Spyros N. Pandis. Atmospheric chemistry and physics : from air pollution to climate change. New York : John Wiley c1998.
6) Asante-Duah, Kofi. Public Health Risk Assessment for Human Exposure to Chemicals. Dordrecht: Springer 2017.

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Spatial Analytics for Environment, Health and Public Management

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: This course provides an introduction of a wide spectrum of spatial analytical models and their applications in environment, health, and public management. The course has two major aims. On the technical front, this course aims to teach students fundamental concepts and recent progress of spatial analysis. On the substantive front, this course integrates the introduction to spatial analytics with their applications in environment, health, and public management, ranging from mapping the inequality among economic and health outcomes, to environmental quality evaluation and innovative census using remote sensing and locational based service. After completing this course, students are expected to have a sound working knowledge of GIS and spatial data analysis and an ability to identify and apply proper analytical methods to problem solving, and to correctly and appropriately interpret and present analysis results.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

* understand concepts central to spatial data analysis
* be aware of the progress and challenges of GIS and spatial analytics in environment, health and public management
* present and interpret spatial data in the context of environment, health, and public management
* identify geographic patterns, understand underlying spatiotemporal processes, and make spatially-explicit prediction/simulation under different decision scenarios
* critically assess management decisions and draw policy implications by virtue of geo-spatial modeling and geo-analysis techniques discussed in class and applied in labs
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Lectures**
Lecture 1: Spatial data and spatial data analysis
Lecture 2: Revealing inequalities (focus: mapping and geo-visualization)
Lecture 3: Taking advantage of special structure (focus: spatial sampling and interpolation)

Lecture 4: Identifying determinants (1) (focus: fundamental statistical analysis methods)
Lecture 5: Identifying determinants (2) (focus: spatial regression and GWR)

Lecture 6: Governing mega-city region (focus: spatial network analysis)
Lecture 7: Allocating resources (focus: spatial optimization)
Lecture 8: Forecasting the future (focus: geo-simulation)
Lecture 9: Citizen as sensors (focus: location-based service)
Lecture 10: Course review

* *Laboratories**
Lab 1: Mapping and geo-visualization
Lab 2: Spatial sampling and interpolation
Lab 3: Conventional correlation/regression analysis
Lab 4: Spatial regression and GWR
Lab 5: Network analysis
Lab 6: Spatial optimization
Lab 7: Geo-simulation
Lab 8: Location-based service (mobile mapping)
courses.required_readings:
* **Basic Textbook:***

Oyana, Tonny J. and Margai, Florence. 2015. *Spatial Analysis – Statistics, Visualization, and Computational Methods*. CRC Press

* **Alternative Textbooks:***

1. Stillwell JCH and Clarke GP. 2004. *Applied GIS and Spatial Analysis*. Chichester, West Sussex, England; Hoboken, NJ: Wiley.
2. O’Sullivan and Unwin. 2010. *Geographic Information Analysis*, 2nd Edition. Wiley.
3. Wang F. 2014. *Quantitative Methods and Socio-Economic Applications in GIS*, 2nd Edition. CRC Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Geospatial Analysis - A comprehensive guide: <http://www.spatialanalysisonline.com/>*A free web-based GIS resource - Dr Michael de Smith and Prof Paul Longley, University College London, and Prof Mike Goodchild, UC Santa Barbara*
2. Applied Spatial Analysis and Policy: <http://link.springer.com/journal/12061>

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Public Health

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: This course is for students intending to gain fundamental knowledge in the discipline of public health. General basic concepts, theories and methodology and scopes of public health practice will be introduced, with some emphases on occupation/environment and health risk assessment. Other important public health topics including air pollution, climate change, food sustainability, water pollution and land use, as well as health promotion and intervention in the community, healthcare management and policy implications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.course_syllabus:
Lectures
Lecture 1: Introduction to public health and determinants of health
Lecture 2: Basic concepts of epidemiology methodology in public health
Lecture 3: Assessing health status in community settings and public health Intervention
Lecture 4: Fundamental of occupational and environmental health
Lecture 5: Shifting focuses of public health linking occupation and environment
Lecture 6: Health risk assessment to tackle important public health issues
Lecture 7: Critical appraisal of study results and public health research reports
Lecture 8: Environmental hazard and health impact
Lecture 9: Overview of environmental epidemiology
Lecture 10: Environmental exposure assessment in public health

Lecture 11: Global Public Health Problem: Air Pollution

Lecture 12: How to use public health approaches to investigate health effects of ambient air pollution
courses.required_readings: * Mary-Jane Schneider, 2016, Introduction to Public Health, USA, Jones and Bartlett Publishers, Inc.
courses.recommended_readings: * Martin Gulliford, Edmund Jessop, 2020, Healthcare Public Health: Improving health services through population science, UK, Oxford University Press

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Geoinformation Technologies for Risk and Crises Management

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: This course is to inform, explain, analyze, interpret and communicate the role of Geoinformation technologies in risk and crises situations (tsunamis, earthquakes, fires, landslides, anthropogenic disasters) and improvement of their use in adequate operations with aim to show their till now under-evaluated potentials and way how to integrate knowledge of cartographic and geographic community to risk and crises management into wide decision making process.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking this course, students are expected to understand fundamental knowledge about risk and crises management, to gain basic and general geoinformation technology framework for risk and crises management, to get technical skills of using remote sensing and GIS for early warning and emergency response, and to understand the assessment of damage and recovery from crises.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Natural Disasters Science
2. Disaster Management Framework (DMF)
3. Geographic Information Science (GIS) for Disaster Management (I): Theory & Technology
4. Geographic Information Science (GIS) for Disaster Management (II): Good Practice
5. Data Preparedness and Data Sharing
6. Risk Assessment and Early Warning
7. Emergence Response
8. Recovery and Post Disaster
9. Remote Sensing (RS) of Natural Disasters
courses.required_readings:
* Haimes, H, Y. 2009, *Risk Modeling, Assessment, and Management*, 3rd edition, Wiley, New York
* Marvin Rausand. 2010, *Risk assessment : theory, methods, and applications*. Wiley, New York
* Milan Konecny, Sisi Zlatanova, Temenoujka L. Bandrova. 2010, *Geographic Information and Cartography for Risk and Crisis Management: Towards Better Solutions*. Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg
courses.recommended_readings:
* Peter van Oosterom, Siyka Zlatanova, Elfriede M. Fendel, *Geo-information for Disaster Management*, Springer
* Woodhouse, Iain H. *Introduction to microwave remote sensing*. CRC press, 2017

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Environmental Remote Sensing Technology

meetings.location: Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303
Fok Ying Tung RS Sci. Bldg 303

courses.description: The course helps students to understand remote sensing principles and basic skills in remote sensing image processing and analysis. The students will develop the capability to solve practical problems in the Earth System Science by using remote sensing methods. The theory, methods, and applications of environmental remote sensing are taught in the course. The lectures cover the principles of electromagnetic radiation, satellite observation sensors, digital image processing, Earth target classifications, and the remote sensing applications in land and ocean. ERDAS Imagine software will be used for lab practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
The course helps students to understand remote sensing principles and basic skills in remote sensing image processing and
analysis. The students will develop the capability to solve practical problems in the Earth System Science by using remote sensing methods.
courses.course_syllabus: The theory, methods, and applications of environmental remote sensing are taught in the course. The lectures cover the principles of electromagnetic radiation, satellite observation sensors, digital image processing, Earth target classifications, and the remote sensing applications in land and ocean. ERDAS Imagine software will be used for lab practices.
courses.required_readings:
* Mather, Paul M. and Magaly Koch, 2011, Computer processing of remotely-sensed images: an introduction, 4th Ed., Chichester, West Sussex, UK ; Hoboken, NJ : Wiley-Blackwell, 434 pages.
* Jensen, John R., 2007, Remote Sensing of the Environment: An Earth Resource Perspective, 2nd Ed., Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 592 pages.
* Jensen, John R., 2004. Introductory Digital Image Processing, 3rd Ed. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 544 pages.
courses.recommended_readings:
* ERDAS Field Guide.
* ERDAS Tour Guide.

courses.subject: ESGS
courses.title: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and Sensor Network for Environmental Monitoring
courses.description:
This course describes broad principles of Environmental Sensor Network (SN), the integration with positioning technologies and its roles in contemporary environmental studies and smart cities developments. The integration of SN and positioning technologies offers a powerful combination of distributed sensing capacity, real time data visualization and spatial analysis and integration with remote sensing data sources. The combined technologies are greatly needed in large-scale environmental monitoring and Smart Cities developments.

Another half of the course introduces the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and other indoor positioning technologies. It covers the basic principles, advanced techniques as well as their applications in Earth System Sciences and urban management. With the background knowledge and the practical skills, students shall be able to integrate GNSS and SN in their future research and studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes: With the background knowledge and the practical skills, students shall be able to integrate GNSS and SN in their future researches and studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Big Picture: Smart City, Big Data and Wireless Environmental Sensor Network

2. Basics of Wireless Communication, sensor node and sensor network

3. Spatial analysis and sensors network

4. Building and Planning a sensor network

5. Indoor Positioning Technologies

6. GNSS Basic 1: Satellite Signal and Error Source

7. GNSS Basic 2: Positioning Methods

8. GNSS and SN Integration

9. Application of GNSS & SN I - Smart City

10. Application of GNSS & SN II - Locational-based Services (LBS)

11. Application of GNSS & SN III - Earth System Science
courses.required_readings:
1. Building Wireless Sensor Network / Robert Faludi, O’Reilly
2. Introduction to GPS : the Global Positioning System / Ahmed El-Rabbany, Artech House
3. Indoor Wayfinding and Navigation / H. A. Karimi, CRC Press
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Handbook of Sensor Networks – Algorithm and Architectures / Ivan Stojmenovic, Wiley-Interscience
2. Integrated approach to environmental data management systems / Nilgun B. Harmancioglu, Kluwer Academic
3. Understanding GPS : principles and applications / Elliott D. Kaplan, Christopher J. Hegarty, editors. Boston : Artech House, c2006.
4. Introduction to GPS : the Global Positioning System / Ahmed El-Rabbany, El-Rabbany, Ahmed.
5. GPS: theory, algorithms and applications / Guochang Xu.New York : Springer, 2003.

courses.description: Earth System Science is a study of the Earth as an integrated system with its major components of atmosphere, hydrosphere lithosphere and biosphere. This seminar course is an open forum which aims at making students acquire up-to-date knowledge and techniques of the Earth system and Geoscience. Well-known scholars, professionals, rescarchers and officals from local institutions and from overseas will be inivited to present their latest research and timely topics relevant to Earth system science.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Geo-survey and Public Management, MSc in Environmental Information, Health and Public Management and MPhil-PhD in Earth System and GeoInformation Science
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will acquire up-to-date knowledge and techniques of the Earth system and Geoscience, and develop a deeper appreciation of the research and topics relevant to the Earth system science.
courses.course_syllabus: This seminar course is an open forum which aims at making students acquire up-to-date knowledge and techniques of the Earth system and Geoscience. Well-known scholars, professionals, researchers and officials from local institutions and from overseas will be invited to present their latest research and timely topics relevant to Earth system science. The course is open to all students and staff. The seminar language will be English or Chinese
